comments.commentBody: I have nothing to add to gn #2, except that for Q3. the probability of having the name alphabetical value equal to 142 is approximately f((169-141)/26)-f((169-142)/26) ~ 0.009 or close to 1%. f is the standard normal cumulative distribution function with mean 0 and standard deviation 1.

I liked GN's approach to question 3, and decided to look at what the average value of a letter would be based on data, rather than the reasonable estimate of 13 (or, perhaps 13.5). The reason thirteen doesn't seem great is because several of the "high-scrabble" letters are late in the alphabet (Q,Z,X) and many of the common letters (A, E, I) are front loaded. I used the website:

http://millikeys.sourceforge.net...

which looked at the frequency of letters in works of fiction. Note that this is also inexact, because these aren't names. To get better, you could use something like a weighted social security index of baby names (starting with http://www.ssa.gov/OACT/babynames/) but that would only get you first names, so I stuck with what was easy.

This data gives an average letter value that is a little lower (11.7). Otherwise the calculation is the same as they did, yielding day 152 or June 1st in any non-leap year.

Elizabeth Tjader , Post No. 3, is so correct about population control. However, this discussion leads to a another area that is just as broad - the nature of the present political economic systems and the ethos underpinning them. Many, if not most industrial economies (capitalism, corporatism, and even most forms of socialism) rely upon continued growth for their viability. To sustain this growth requires the people consuming more. Coupled with this is the structure of the younger generations through retirement funds, etc. supporting the older persons no longer in the workforce. Perforce, biology seems to mandate that the more able bodied support the aging population, and with time, there must be more (increased population) of those able-bodied persons. In the US many persons receiving funds from the Social security (SS) SS fund but do not have other funds to support themselves, thus needing to find work. I suspect that such is the case in many other industrialized countries. Additionally, there is an ever increasing burden on infrastructure of health and other social services, and this requires correspondingly increasing revenue. In places like the US, this problem is exacerbated by the lack of a truly universally accessible health care system. The recently passed "health care" bill is not adequate, as it imposes intolerable expenses (to the benefit of the insurance company parasites) on the average worker. For social security recipients, for whom an an upper end check would amount to a few hundreds of dollars over a thousand, the Medicare expenses often amount to $100 or even $200 dollars. Without supplemental income, such is quite a burden. This says nothing about out-of-pocket expenses for "Plan B" and/or "Plan C". As a result of the lack of a civilized health care and social services system taxpayers wind up paying even more for emergency responses. This requires more taxpayers, i.e., population growth.

All this indicates that industrial growth requires population growth. At some point, the whole industrial economy ideology of continued increased growth and production to keep money in circulation (velocity of capital) must be supplanted by systems that rely upon a steady state and even declining material status. Why, for example do people think they need two, three, or even more of anything, as opposed to a basic set of whatever to make life commodious.

Not only must the population be reduced to pull back from the environmental abyss, but we need to have a serious amount of introspection as to our values, i.e., what is meaningful in life. Surely, there must be higher values that consumerism, materialism, and greed. Any empty head can sustain these. Even hogs can do better; apparently, they are rather intelligent. From my admittedly prejudicial perspective, I such a good start to addressing population growth and attendant environmental destruction would be philosophy and meditation.

It's true that Breakthrough has been a great advocate for making 'clean energy cheap.' It's a really important point, and they have made it well - in the face of much opposition. On the other hand, the promise of lots of federal R&D does not in any way replace the power of what a carbon price can do - imposed via a tax or an equivalent cap. See this recent post at Politico: http://www.politico.com... The sure signal that investors like these guys are looking for can only come from a carbon price, and a large one at that. That signal complements the promise of more R&D; neither is a substitute for another.

And each of these policies, to get mildly nerdy, maps to two different, very real discount rates: that used by firms and that which should be used by society. The former drives investment decision for a 5 - 20 year time horizon - the utility asking 'should we build a coal plant or not?' The latter should drive investment decisions of the 15 - 30 year time horizon: the Department of Energy asking 'what's the best way to invest in CCS even if it won't be in the market for a good decade or two?'

I have taught my three children to be environmentally aware. I recycle. I support every effort to find alternatives to fossil fuels. I donate to environmental causes. Gas mileage minimums are not a bad idea either. I have two college degrees and have tried to educate myself regarding environmental issues for the last 25 years or so. I don't own stock in oil companies. I don't mind paying more in taxes if it is used responsibly. I would also say that my views fall in line with the vast majority of "conservatives" that I know.

There are reasons why a very significant portion of the population and scientific community do not support calls for sweeping, immediate and expensive solutions to what we all refer to as global warming. The evidence is not as clear as many would like to believe it is, and many of the solutions offered amount to costly guesses. Nobody is fooling me, or paying me, or necessarily smarter than me.

I would remind people how much progress has been made in the last century, and the scientific and technological advances we have seen. Essentially everybody wants a cleaner world, and much better sources of energy. The difference is that I have tremendous faith in our ability to find the best solutions. I have very little faith in governments to do so, or in people who think they have all the answers when they clearly do not. The combination of these two will result in the wasting of countless dollars on programs of minimal consequence, except to the generations of people who will end up paying for them.

A 5 step emergency program may need to be the next step.

...Arctic Now Near Climate Tipping Point reads the headline in a June 29th article carried by the Environmental News Service. 400 parts per million of carbon now appears to be the critical figure. We are approaching 390 ppm and have been adding 2 ppm each year. As most readers are aware, the safe limit is 350 ppm.

A scientist has suggested that should sufficient Gulf oil enter the Atlantic to provide a very thin reflective film in the North Atlantic and Arctic oceans - that could accelerate the Tipping Point, a self-amplifying feedback loop, with life threatening implications for polar bears and walruses.

In Ticking Time Bomb, John Atcheson warned of the Tipping Point threat posed by melting permafrost in the Arctic. He points out that twice before life on earth was the victim of Tipping Points. One of those events reduced life to single celled organisms. Millions of years were required to recover.

It seems it is not too late to prevent much of the oil in the Gulf from entering the Atlantic. It has been suggested a boom and weir barrier can be put in place between Key West and Cuba by a flotilla of fishing boats and pleasure craft.

The 5 Step Program:

1. Check the facts: A place to start might be to read Ticking Time Bomb, Methane Tipping Point Threat and Worst Case Scenario. All have been reposted at www.aesopinstitute.org
2. Contain the oil: Effective techniques are available. Put them to work on an emergency basis 24/7;
3. Supersede fossil fuels as fast as is humanly possible. This could create millions of public and private sector jobs;
4. Find ways to generate necessary public support to insure Government action in time;
5. Ironically, this program will help create the additional stimulus required to truly revive the economy.

If human life on earth is truly threatened, superseding oil and fossil fuels is possible much more rapidly that might be imagined. As a first step, every variety of renewable energy technology, that might be deployed in time, should be encouraged by means of suitable incentives to sharply increase production.

Moving Beyond Oil, on the Aesop Institute site, mentions a couple of revolutionary, very difficult to believe, technologies. Consider the positive impact of a 24/7 program of validation, development and production.

Renewables are not expensive or difficult to scale.  The problem at the moment is that we have invested pitifully tiny amounts or R&D on them. (Look it up.) If we had spent a small % of the budget of our recent wars, bailouts, or the cost of a few (of the 90 or so) nuke plants on renewable R&D instead, we would have had cheap energy decades ago. But corps do not want to make that investment; they want to sell the milk, not the cow.  So this investment is the a gov't responsibility, and until either (a) voters understand what's going on and demand change or (b) politicians actually lead, progress will be slow, and pundits will continue to say "renewables are expensive."  Not so.

I think the article by Christian Parenti in the recent Freedom From Oil issue of the nation which calls for a Big Green Buy by all levels of government is the most sensible suggestion I've seen for some time. Innovation is needed, for sure, but his approach would get us going NOW and avoid the great difficulty posed by the strong efforts of the gas and oil industries to maintain the unstainable status quo. Congressional approval would not be required and there would be no waiting for some innovation to arise from labs - which, if it happened, would just be some additional frosting to get us to where we need to be faster. Let the private sector and the super-rich, with their piles of cash, do the innovation and let the governments do the Big Green Buy.

Elizabeth #3,

While in general, I agree that it is socially and environmentally convenient to limit human population growth, I strongly disagree with your assumption that population growth is necessarily in a direct relationship with energy consumption. See the following link and observe that countries with relatively high population growth like Indonesia, Pakistan, and Bangladesh consume less energy than those countries where population growth is minimal or almost zero like Japan, France, Germany, and the US. I believe we should first talk about modes of production, distribution, and consumption of goods, which are for the most part anarchic and address socially created wants instead of human basic needs. We need to prioritize our policies to effectively reduce superfluous energy use and overcome poverty and ignorance. That is the end product of equality and democracy. Otherwise, we run the risk of running into facile and reductionist solutions that eventually end up blaming the victims of those who actually waste energy producing and selling useless trinkets.

JNB has it exactly right. The "price gap" between the true cost of fossil fuels and renewables is, in many cases, small or negative. In particular, coal-powered electricity would be phased out as fast as replacements could be built, if its producers were ever held accountable for paying for all the damage it causes. These damages include the deaths of around 10,000 Americans every year! Why do those on the right throw the mother of all hissy fits about terrorism, which doesn't even average 5% of that figure, yet ignore a problem that is orders of magnitude larger?

Putting the a price on carbon will take some guesswork, but whatever number gets turned out, it will still be a lot closer than the current price of zero. That will cause the market to use more accurate prices as its inputs, and therefore produce a superior output.

46 JNB: Uranium is NOT a fossil fuel. Fossil fuels are called fossil fuels because you find fossils in them, or they originated with ancient living things. Oil and gas, being fluid, don't have fossils, but they came from once living things. You can find lots of fossilized plants in coal. You don't find fossils in uranium mines, but you could get your uranium from coal cinders and ashes. You CAN get uranium and thorium and arsenic, lead and a long list of minerals from coal cinders and ashes. In fact, the Manhattan project considered coal ashes and cinders as its source for uranium.

Coal fired power plants put 100 to 400 times as much radioactivity into the environment as nuclear plants are allowed to. Our nuclear power plants could be fully fueled by the uranium in coal ashes and cinders. Average coal contains 1 or 2 parts per million uranium. A 1000 megawatt coal fired power plant burns 4 Million tons of coal each year. Multiplying that out, the coal fired power plant ashes contain 4 to 8 tons of uranium per year, which is plenty to fuel an equal sized Generation 2 nuclear plant for a year.

Isn't it strange that the coal fired power plant gets to dump its nuclear waste without objection, and coal cinders and ashes are used as building materials?

I was just in Canada, where per capita energy expenditure (and carbon emissions) are slightly greater than in the United States, due to colder winters and epic distances between cities.  Gas taxes were well over $1/gallon, but it didn't seem to be bringing the economy to its knees-- things seemed somewhat more prosperous than in the States.  We so obviously overestimate the economic costs of moderate taxation and regulation of fossil fuels to help contain our outrageous usage.  Even putting aside the climate issue, which while irrefutably dangerous is, unfortunately, not solely in our citizens' control, making it still more difficult to take action on-- the simple fact is that as living standards increase in the developing world, the era of cheap, easily available fossil fuels will soon be over.  It is the obligation of public policy in the United States to help contain our runaway usage of fuel, not just to save the planet, but to soften the near-term (as in before 2020, I would guess) shock to our economy that rapidly escalating fuel costs will deliver.  It should be remembered that while  the global recession sent fuel prices down a peg, the 2.5 billion people living in India, China, and South America experienced rising living standards throughout 2009 and 2010, and increased their energy usage accordingly.  The major oil companies are already forced not just into dangerous, deepwater drilling to find new reserves, but into the hugely wasteful use of oil sands. The effects on prices are only a couple years away, and beginning to regulate and tax fossil fuels now, so as to facilitate a transition to a less energy-intensive future, is economically as well as ecologically wise.
